Working with mirror data

Source: vignettes/articles/mirror-data.Rmd
mirror-data.Rmd

A more complex example

Let’s say you want to download monthly mirror trade data starting in 2019 at the HS4 6-digit level for a handful of countries.

While there are multiple areas where both comtrade and WITS offer similar functionality to the comtradeRggregator package, this is a scenario where both alternatives are tedious to work with:

  • While WITS does offer a straight-forward integration of mirror data, there are (at the time of writing this documentation in 2021) no options available to query monthly data;

  • While comtrade does over the most recent and granular trade data, the options to query mirror data are limited.

As I will demonstrate below, this data can be obtained via comtradeRggregator with little to no additional effort.

Implementation

First, load the package.

library(comtradeRggregator)

Define list of countries for extraction

country_list = c("Afghanistan", "Angola")

Let’s break up this query into two parts: a download for the years 2019 and 2020, and a separate query for 2021. In such somewhat more elaborate cases, it is advisable to keep any temporarily downloaded data by setting rm.temporaryFiles = FALSE. I also want to save the temporary files in a different location specified in variable my_location, so I also specify location.temporaryFiles = my_location in the query below. In an ideal world, you will have access to an authenticated account (see here). I do, so I’m also providing my comtrade authentication token as part of the query. Finally, as we do not want to overwhelm the API, we reduce the number of extracted countries per sub-query to three, i.e. ext_cnt = 3, instead of the default of five, and increase the cool-down period between the separate queries from five to ten seconds between rounds by setting speed = 10. These last two steps are optional and only serve illustrative purposes.

Note that for the first query we are not specifying the parameter month which, by default, will return data for all 12 months.

mirr_part1 <- download_Comtrade(
  year = c("2019", "2020"),
  frequency = "monthly",
  countries = country_list,
  partners = "World",
  nomenclature = "HS2012",
  commodity = "ag6",
  select.stats = "trade_value_usd",
  direction = "all",
  type = "commodities",
  is.mirrorData = TRUE,
  rm.temporaryFiles = FALSE,
  location.temporaryFiles = my_location,
  build.Comtrade = TRUE,
  token = my_token,
  ext_cnt  = 3,
  sleep = 10
)

Finally, we want to find the last month of 2021 for which any comtrade data is available to download.

You can either use the is.available_Comtrade() function for this, or, alternatively, the data file Comtrade_DA, which provides comtrade’s data availability as a tibble. At the time of writing this tutorial, the most recent monthly trade data is July 2021.

Comtrade_DA %>% 
  mutate(yr = substr(ps, 1, 4), mnth = substr(ps, 5,6)) %>% 
  filter(freq == "MONTHLY" & yr == '2021' ) %>%
  summarise(x = max(mnth))
#> # A tibble: 1 x 1
#>   x    
#>   <chr>
#> 1 07
mirr_part2 <- download_Comtrade(
  year = c("2021"),
  frequency = "monthly",
  month = c("01":"07"),
  countries = country_list,
  partners = "World",
  nomenclature = "HS2012",
  commodity = "ag6",
  select.stats = "trade_value_usd",
  direction = "all",
  type = "commodities",
  is.mirrorData = TRUE,
  rm.temporaryFiles = FALSE,
  location.temporaryFiles = my_location,
  build.Comtrade = TRUE,
  token = my_token,
  ext_cnt  = 3,
  sleep = 10
)
